study_title: Prime Editing Corrects RBM20-Mediated Dilated Cardiomyopathy in Human Cardiomyocytes
study_abstract: The goal of the study is to establish Prime Editing (PE) in differentiated, non-dividing human cardiomyocytes to precisely repair patient-derived DCM mutations to wildtype. We focus on three pathogenic DCM-causing mutations within the human LMNA and RBM20 genes. Our results support further pre-clinical development of PE-based therapies, particularly for RBM20-P633L-associated DCM

experiment_title: Targeted-Capture of homo sapiens: adult DCM patient No.45
study_abstract: Dilated cardiomyopathy is a severe disease with a dismal prognosis that can lead to heart failure requiring a transplant or patient death. However, the genetic mechanisms underlying the disease are still unclear. To explore the pathogenesis of dilated cardiomyopathy, we recruited 198 patients (142 patients with DCM and 56 controls) and exome sequencing was performed using the peripheral whole blood samples obtained from the participants.In total, 2 samples (2 patients in DCM group) were excluded from further analysis due to poor quality.

study_abstract: Next Generation Sequencing approach to determine the mutation spectrum in Indian patients with Familial Hypercholesterolemia

experiment_title: DCM Precision Medicine Study Exomes: Sample SAM1144
sample_title: Non-tumor DNA sample from Blood of a human male participant in the dbGaP study "Precision Medicine for Dilated Cardiomyopathy in European and African Ancestry"
study_title: Precision medicine for dilated cardiomyopathy in European and African ancestry
study_abstract: The DCM Precision Medicine Study is a multi-site consortium-based cross-sectional study of families with an embedded open-label randomized controlled trial. The aims of the study are to test the hypothesis that dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) has a substantial genetic basis and to evaluate the effectiveness of a family communication intervention in improving the uptake of preventive screening and surveillance in at-risk first-degree relatives. The Study goal was to recruit 1,300 individuals (600 non-Hispanic African ancestry, 600 non-Hispanic European ancestry, and 100 Hispanic; 50% female) meeting rigorous diagnostic criteria for idiopathic DCM (probands) and 2,600 of their relatives. The probands were inpatients or outpatients identified by heart failure and cardiac transplant... (for more see dbGaP study page.)

experiment_title: AB SOLiD 4 System paired end sequencing
study_title: Genetic analysis of arrhythmogenic diseases in the era of NGS: the complexity of clinical decision-making in Brugada Syndrome.
study_abstract: A cohort of 45 clinically diagnosed Brugada Syndrome patients classified as SCN5A-negative was analyzed using next generation sequencing. Twenty-eight genes were resequenced. A total of 85 clinically evaluated relatives were also genetically analyzed to ascertain familial segregation.  We identified genetic variants in novel candidate genes potentially associated to Brugada Syndrome. The identification of these genetic variants opens new perspectives on the implications of genetic background in the arrhythmogenic substrate for research purposes.
